subject: RE: [junit] thoughts on fail(); in generated tests
msgSnippet: [Repost. Pardon the =20 and =2Es]  ... If you mean, that in a non-TDD environment, there are many empty test methods in the beginning, that is true.
messageBody:
[Repost. Pardon the =20 and =2Es]

<quote>
> This is all definitely worth knowing, but my immediate guess is that
> the JUnitDoclet user is (re)generating far too many tests at once,
> irrespective of whether those tests say fail() or not

If you mean, that in a non-TDD environment, there are many
empty test methods in the beginning, that is true. (The next
version of JUnitDoclet will at least count them and print that
number as warning.) But as a coach I actually have seen a
remarkable thing:

Because it is so easy to write a test _then_ (once there is
a place for it) they get written naturally. Developers know
the importance of tests, the just need help to get started.
</quote>

It is easy to write a test then, but it's not necessarily the proper test
to write=2E Test-After leads to a testing methods, rather than testing
behavior=2E One of the points of TDD is to identify what behavior is requi=
red
up front, then implement just enough of it=2E There is already overhead to=

writing unnecessary code; there is much more overhead in testing
unnecessary code=2E Generating test stubs abdicates the programmer of his
responsibility to ask himself the question, "Do I need to test this method=
?
Do I even need this method at all?" That's one reason why I distrust the
Test-After process=2E

Still, that's easy for me to say, because I don't have millions of lines o=
f
untested (and untestable) legacy code standing between me and the delivery=

date=2E I have respect for the people who effectively deal with that probl=
em=2E

<quote>
> It is important for us to remember our TDD bias=2E :)

BTW: Did you ever consider to generate a test from an empty=20
but compilable application method? Still the test can be=20
_implemented_ before the tested method does something=2E=20
</quote>

Yes, I have considered it; but I prefer to write the test first, because i=
n
so doing, I may find out that the method I wanted to write really needs to=

be something else entirely=2E

I have had this discussion with quite a few of my (then) IBM colleagues,
one of whom asserts that writing the test immediately after writing the
code is the same as writing the test before the code=2E The bottom line is=

that as long as the individual thinks about the test first, that's what is=

important=2E To do otherwise creates more problems to refactor away from=2E=


Take care=2E

--JBR
